Award.AwardTitle: Soil Slips Versus Flow Failures in Rain-Infiltrated Slopes: Using Mechanical Stability Principles to Enhance Spatially Distributed Models for Landslide Forecasting

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to contribute to the transformative advancement of physically-based models for landslide forecasting. This objective will be pursued by incorporating novel concepts of soil stability into the failure criteria for natural slopes. Particular attention will be given to the effects of climatic forcing and rain infiltration, which are known to change the water-pressure regime, deteriorate the strength properties of geotechnical materials and cause dramatic failures in slopes and earthworks. The project will use innovative methods to capture multiple types of failure (e.g., localized slips or flow-like instabilities). These criteria will be combined with the simulation of the hydrologic response of soil veneers, thus allowing the prediction of the potential for unstable ground movements at regional scale. The project will consider specific cases of landscapes which have suffered pervasive landsliding during rainfall events. For these cases, we will generate charts of critical triggering perturbations for given combinations of morphologic features, geotechnical properties and hydrologic conditions. The expected outcome is to formulate new quantitative methods to control the evolving state of stability in natural and urbanized landscapes through physically-based simulations.

Findings from this project will benefit society by enhancing the ability to locate different types of slope failure via physical modeling. Depending on site-specific features, soil covers can fail either in the form of slides with limited mobility or as rapid flows. Several cases around the world have demonstrated the dramatic implications of these differences, as rapid landslides may involve considerable damages to property and the loss of human lives. The physical understanding of hillslope dynamics fostered by this project will play a role in the management of natural disasters. In particular, the incorporation of scientific findings into the practice of landslide forecasting can have broad societal and educational impacts for risk assessment and land-use planning in several areas of the world. In addition, an improved understanding of soil failure in natural settings will impact a broad range of problems dominated by the interplay between human activities and geomorphic processes, such as soil erosion, sediment transport and river-channel management. Education and outreach initiatives will be integrated to capitalize on the research components of the project, including international experiences for graduate students and an integrated educational initiative for engineering and geoscience students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Landslide hazards are a source of property and life loss in densely populated countries. The increase in population and the associated spread of cities in previously inhabited areas exacerbates the exposure of human communities to such calamitous events. Given the reluctance of policy makers to long-term investments in hazard mitigation, land-use regulations and early-warning systems are the only cost-effective methods to guarantee sustainable growth and minimize losses. The development of knowledge and technical expertise in this area of science has therefore major potential benefits for society, as new findings can transform the assessment of natural risks, thus impacting the methods currently used to track hazardous landslides and locate high-vulnerability regions across the world.

Within such class of geoghazards, rainfall-induced slope instabilities are major life-threatening events. Although it is widely accepted that shallow soil veneers fail in different ways, current forecasting models do not capture such variability, in that they postulate frictional failure as the only form of instability. In this project, new landslide forecasting tools have been formulated to quantify in a unified manner the risks of localized slips (i.e., landslides of limited mobility) and flowslides (i.e., rapid movements triggered by liquefaction). The project used a multi-scale methodology based on the analysis of soil failure at both laboratory and regional scale. Different mechanisms of strength deterioration were described in mathematical terms, with the purpose to obtain analytical expressions of the margin of safety for multiple modes of landslide initiation. These safety factors were eventually incorporated in numerical models able to simulate infiltration over large areas and identify the portions of a landscape susceptible to life-threatening flows.   

The findings of the project demonstrate that the simultaneous assessment of different failure mechanisms enhances the predictive capability of spatially distributed models. Parametric studies showed indeed that the interplay between soil properties and climate forcing has a major impact on the accuracy of the forecast. Specifically, it was found that changes in the initial state caused by fluctuations of the hydrologic conditions prior to a rainstorm may lead to substantial changes in the predicted time of failure, as well as to alterations of the mobilized volumes and the degree of post-failure mobility. 

Such findings suggest that advanced process-based models should be evaluated in terms of different spatial, temporal and morphometric indices to allow a comprehensive inspection of the model response. In addition, they provide insight on the physics of rainfall-induced landslides by suggesting that the interaction between soil deformation and fluid flow is one of the factors responsible for the variability of landslide triggering mechanisms. To study these feedbacks, not only rich spatially-distributed datasets and landslides inventories are required, but also physically-based models incorporating the complexity of soil behavior are needed.
